text: As India turns 70
column4: a sombre reminder of stolen freedoms | My article in @scroll_in https://t.co/LUU15G553e

text: & 5 died
column4: immersed neck-deep in human excreta
column5: breathing toxic fumes in dark underground sewers of Delhi
column6: as we approached 70 ys of freedom

text: Jharkhand CM misused Gandhi—who died for religious tolerance & love between diverse faiths—to foster hatred & division based on religion
PM & RSS did not just insult Hamid Ansari but every Indian Muslim by dismissing rising fear among minorities in growing hatred & lynching
By belligerent sarcasm of the Prime Minister
column4: exhibiting his lifelong hostility to the country’s religious minorities

text: …of how in myriad ways that freedom continues to be stolen from millions of our historically most oppressed peoples
As India celebrates 70 years of freedom
column4: there are worrying reminders for religious minorities and the oppressed castes and class...

text: Let's make some amends with a journey of shared suffering
column4: solidarity

text: We hope to include chroniclers—writers
column4: poets
column6: videographers—who will record what they see as we travel for the rest of us

text: We invite writers
column4: poets
column5: musicians & artists to join Karawan-e-Mohabbat to respond to rising darkness of hate violence & lynching in India

text: It would be wonderful if any of you could be part of this
column4: for some or all of the Karawan

text: The month-long Karawan-e-Mohabbat will take us to families that have lost loved ones to hate lynching — to share pain and love
Karawan-e-Mohabbat is a journey of shared suffering
column4: solidarity

text: I hope my comrades and I will be able to locate at least within ourselves our collective capacities for radical love.
In battling ideologies that harvest hate
column4: we can only win equipped with love. We need to garner across our land a plenitude of acts of love

text: Darkness can't be fought with darkness
column4: only light can dispel shadows.Politics of hate can only be fought with politics of love & solidarity

text: With pain & shame
column4: we'll seek from them our collective forgiveness
column6: to share their suffering. And to speak to them of our love

text: In Sept
column4: we'll travel from Assam to Gujarat
column6: to meet families who lost loved ones to hate lynching

text: Come join us on a journey of shared suffering
column4: of atonement and of love. SAFAR DARD KA

text: There is much that we must do to fight this rising darkness. My article in @IndianExpress https://t.co/Jqr4FcT9eg
What is new is the frequency and the normalisation of this lynching
column4: in a growing aggressively majoritarian political and social environment

text: There is a rising darkness in India. Mobs are acting out visceral hatred everywhere — on highways
column4: in train compartments

text: Because I worry that
column4: if allowed to go unchecked
column5: lynching could become a national epidemic. My article in @htTweets https://t.co/VUmYHQxhM8

text: A law should make authorities accountable to fulfill constitutional duties to protect the vulnerable from hate attacks and ensure justice.
I argue that a law against lynching should not add to the powers of the state or abridge the rights of the accused.
The soldier in his uniform is not India’s only true patriot – there are heroes everywhere. My article in @scroll_in https://t.co/Q0IHcX6Bm2
Who can tell them that the only true – or at least the purest – way to love your country is to wear a green uniform and pick up a gun?
All of these and a million others love their country in their own way.
I can be a man who travels 100s of km every year for back-breaking work so my kids can eat & study
column4: spared the life to which I was condemned

text: I can be a student who rousingly calls for true equality & azadi for all
column4: I can be a woman who fights violence inside my home and outside it

text: I can wear a khaki uniform
column4: a doc's white coat
column5: a lawyer's black robe or the proverbial jhola of an activist or I can wear no uniform at all

text: I fight against a hierarchy of patriotism that privileges the soldier in an olive green uniform above all others.
JNUVC wants to set up a tank on campus to inspire students. Inspire them to be what? Do soldiers represent exclusive pinnacle of patriotism?
